wikipedia_page.main: Walter Powell (17 April 1842 – 10 December 1881) was a Welsh colliery owner and Conservative politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1868 to 1881. He was carried out over the English Channel in a balloon and never seen again.

response: | Walter PowellDisappeared on a balloon flight

At Great Somerford, Methodists bought the red brick village reading room in 1882 for use as a chapel. (The reading room had been built in 1872 at the expense of Wiltshire MP Walter Powell and was sold following his death.) In 2016 the building was still in use as a Methodist church within the North Wiltshire circuit, holding fortnightly services which alternate with the church at Cleverton.

The first purpose-built school at Great Somerford was built in 1828, then enlarged in 1850, 1870 and 1895. Children of all ages attended until 1954, when those aged 11 and over went to Malmesbury secondary school. In 1982, Somerfords' Walter Powell Primary School was built on a new site to the east of the village, to replace the 19th-century school and that at Little Somerford.
*10 December – Walter Powell, industrialist and politician, 39
*Walter Powell, Conservative MP and colliery owner
* Walter Powell (politician) (1842–1881), British Member of Parliament for Malmesbury, 1868–1882

List of people who disappeared mysteriously: pre-1910
response: |Walter Powell was an English Member of Parliament for Malmesbury, Wiltshire. On 10 December 1881 he went up in a balloon with two friends; Captain James Templer and Mr. A. Agg-Gardner. They attempted to descend in Bridport, Dorset but the balloon hit the ground hard, causing Templer to fall out and the balloon to rise up again with Powell and Agg-Gardner still on board. Agg-Gardner fell out and broke his leg, while Powell remained on board. Neither he nor the balloon were ever seen again.
